titleStmt.title: John Springs et al. to Thomas E. Bramlette
CWG7281

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Thomas E. Bramlette: Governor's official correspondence file, petitions for pardons, remissions, and respites 1863-1867

body.p:
Hon Thos E. Bramlett.
Gov of Kentucky

your petitioners Loyal Unconditional Union men of Crittenden Union & Other Counties Would respectfully State that at the Crittenden Circuit Court held in November 1865, that the grand Jury found a true bill for murder in the first degree against Capt Fountain F Hawkins late of the 15th Regt Ky Cavalry ^afterwards of the 48 mnt infantry^ for Shooting and Killing one William Brantley of Crittenden County Ky, while on a Scout through that County at the head of his Command hunting guerrillas, that were Known to be harboured by Said Brantley and others in his neighbourhood, Capt Hawkins went there for the purpose of arresting said Brantley by the order of Majr Henry of the Regt. He the said Brantley refused to be arrested and swore he would not be arrested by no damd Negro theives and Started into his house where he had armes, refuse to stop when ordered to halt by Capt Hawkins, Brantly being a desperate man, Capt Hawkins
Knowing Brantly to be a desperate man was compelled to fire on him to save his or life or the life of some of his Command, and Brantley was Killed. this happened in the year 1863 in the Summer Winter
Capt Hawkins returned to Paducah give himself up to the Military and was tried and acquitted

This many of your petitioners Know as they were present at the time Brantley was Killed as well as at Capt Hawkins trial, Brantley was a bitter Rebel and although an old man a dangerous one considered so by his neighbours,

and your petitioners will further State that all rebels and rebel sympathisers in this Section of Kentucky, are determined to harrass the Union Soldiers and citizens as much as lies in their power guilty or not and to Screen all the rebels & rebel Sympathisers. this we Know by the Grand Juries refusing to find bills against Known and avowed Guerrillas, who have infested our Country Steeling horses robbing citizens of money robbing Stores and Shooting federal Soldiers that they found Sick or Wounded,

Under these Circumstances your Petitiones Loyal and Unconditional Union men
ask your excellency to pardon Fontain P Hawkins now in Jail in Henderson Ky having been removed from Crittenden Jail
Your petitioners will further state that the Jail was broken open and some others taken and but Capt Hawkins refused to go Knowing he was innocent of the Charge of Murder against him
and your petitioners well ever pray &c &c
names of members of company present at the trial

ut through that County at the head of his men hunting Gurrillars that were known to be harboured by Said -- Brantly and others in the neighbourhood Hawkins went to Brantley for the purpose of arresting him. he refused to be arrested -- and Started into his house where he had armes -- making threats -- This statement Some of Your petitioners know as we was present at the time. And know that Brantly was a bitter Rebal and a da^i^ngerous man so considered by his neighbours When Brantly refused to be arrested and started in his house where he had armes Capt Hawkins Shot him
